choices.text: Inhibition of cell proliferation
Promotion of apoptosis
Stimulation of angiogenesis
Activation of cell signaling pathways

questions.text: 45-year-old woman is diagnosed with breast cancer, and her tumor cells demonstrate overexpression of the HER2/neu proto-oncogene. What is the primary mechanism by which HER2/neu contributes to the pathophysiology of her cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Activation of cell signaling pathways

Option D:

Proto-oncogene HER2/neu encodes for a protein that is a receptor for growth factors. Its over-expression can lead to excessive activation of downstream cell signaling pathways, including the PI3K/Akt and MAPK/Erk pathways, which promote cell proliferation and survival. HER2/neu overexpression is associated with a more aggressive breast cancer phenotype and poorer prognosis.

HER2/neu is a receptor tyrosine kinase that, when overexpressed, results in the excessive activation of downstream signaling pathways, including PI3K/Akt and MAPK/Erk, that are known to promote cell proliferation and survival.

Explanation:

Option A.  Inhibition of cell proliferation is not associated with HER2/neu overexpression; instead, HER2/neu leads to increased cell proliferation.

Option B. Promotion of apoptosis is not a mechanism of HER2/neu action. In contrast, HER2/neu overexpression tends to confer resistance to apoptotic signals.

Option C. While HER2/neu overexpression can have downstream effects that might indirectly promote angiogenesis, this is not the primary action of the proto-oncogene.

Educational Objective:

Overexpression of the HER2/neu proto-oncogene in breast cancer leads to the activation of cell signaling pathways that promote cell proliferation and survival. This overexpression is associated with a more aggressive disease phenotype and a poorer prognosis. Targeted therapies against HER2/neu can be effective in treating tumors with this over-expression.

choices.text: Invasive ductal carcinoma
Invasive lobular carcinoma
Medullary carcinoma
Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman undergoes a breast biopsy after a suspicious mammogram. Histological examination reveals a tumor with lack of tubule formation, discohesive cells and a low mitotic rate. Immunohistochemistry shows positive estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) staining. What is the most likely histological type of breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Invasive lobular carcinoma

 

Option B:

 

Invasive lobular carcinoma (ILC) is characterized by a lack of tubule formation, discohesive cells that infiltrate the stroma in a single-file pattern, and a low mitotic rate. ILC is often ER and PR positive. The classic histological features include a targetoid appearance, known as "Indian file" pattern.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Invasive ductal carcinoma tends to form glandular structures and does not usually present with the "Indian file" pattern of cell arrangement seen in invasive lobular carcinoma.

 

Option C. Medullary carcinoma has a higher mitotic rate and a lymphocytic infiltrate, which differs from the low mitotic rate and discohesive cells described in the biopsy report.

 

Option D. Ductal carcinoma in situ represents an early form of breast cancer that is confined to the ducts and usually forms duct-like structures, unlike the pattern described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Invasive lobular carcinoma is characterized by the absence of tubule formation, discohesive cells, a low mitotic rate, and positive hormone receptor status.

choices.text: 17p
17q
13q
13p

questions.text: A 46-year-old female presents to her family physician because she palpated a nodule in her left breast during a breast self-examination. She subsequently undergoes a partial mastectomy. The mass is examined by a pathologist who makes a diagnosis of invasive ductal carcinoma. Subsequent genetic testing reveals a mutation of the BRCA2 gene. Of the following, what is the location for this mutation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 13q

Option C:

13q indicates the long arm of chromosome 13, which is the correct location for the BRCA2 gene associated with breast cancer.

Explanation:

Option A.  17p refers to the short arm of chromosome 17, which is where the gene for the p53 protein is located, not BRCA2. p53 is commonly mutated in many forms of cancer.

Option B. 17q refers to the long arm of chromosome 17. This is the location of the BRCA1 gene, not BRCA2.

Option D. 13p would refer to the short arm of chromosome 13, which is not the correct location for the BRCA2 gene.

Educational Objective:

The BRCA2 gene is located on the long arm of chromosome 13, at the cytogenetic band 13q.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th ed/ 293-4

choices.text: It is a proto-oncogene
It is involved in cell cycle regulation
It is a tumor suppressor gene
It is not involved in breast cancer

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of breast cancer. They undergo genetic testing, which reveals a mutation in the BRCA1 gene. Which of the following is true about BRCA1?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is a tumor suppressor gene

Option C:

  • BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes for a protein involved in DNA repair. Mutations in the BRCA1 gene are associated with an increased risk of developing breast and ovarian cancers. The protein produced by the BRCA1 gene is involved in repairing DNA damage and preventing the formation of tumors.

It is a tumor suppressor gene. BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene that encodes for a protein involved in DNA repair. Mutations in this gene can lead to an increased risk of developing breast and ovarian cancers due to the loss of effective DNA damage repair, which can result in the accumulation of mutations that contribute to tumor formation.

Explanation:

Option A. It is a proto-oncogene. Proto-oncogenes are genes that normally help cells grow. When a proto-oncogene mutates or becomes overactive, it becomes an oncogene and can lead to cancer. BRCA1, however, is known as a tumor suppressor gene.

Option B. It is involved in cell cycle regulation. While the BRCA1 gene does play a role in cell cycle regulation as part of its function in response to DNA damage, it is more specifically characterized as a gene involved in DNA repair pathways, particularly double-strand break repair.

Option D. It is not involved in breast cancer. This statement is incorrect as mutations in the BRCA1 gene are well-established risk factors for breast cancer, as well as ovarian cancer.

Educational Objective:

BRCA1 gene is a tumor suppressor gene involved in DNA repair. Mutations in BRCA1 increase the risk of breast and ovarian cancers by impairing the repair of DNA damage, which prevents the proper regulation of cell growth and division, thereby contributing to tumorigenesis.

choices.text: p53
BRCA-1
Retinoblastoma (Rb)
H-Ras

questions.text: Increased susceptibility to sporadic breast cancer is likely to be associated with a mutation in the following gene?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) p53

 

Option A:

 

Breast cancer can be either familial (associated with germline mutation) or sporadic (associated with somatic mutation).

 

The p53 gene, known for its role in cell cycle control and apoptosis, is associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome. This hereditary condition predisposes individuals to a variety of cancers, including breast cancer, at an early age. Sporadic breast cancer is associated with mutation in p53 gene (p53 defect is present in 40% of human breast cancer as an acquired defect) and PTEN gene.

 

Since, incidence of sporadic cancer is much more than familial cancer, so the most important gene mutation increasing susceptibility to breast cancer should be answered as p53.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The BRCA1 gene mutation carries a high risk for developing breast and ovarian cancers. Individuals with this mutation have a lifetime risk of breast cancer that is significantly higher than the general population.

 

Option C. While the Rb gene is crucial in controlling cell proliferation and its mutation is primarily associated with retinoblastoma, it is not a leading cause of breast cancer.

 

Option D. H-Ras is part of the Ras gene family; while mutations in these genes can lead to cancer, they are not typically associated with hereditary breast cancer syndromes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The p53 gene mutation is the most important gene mutation increasing susceptibility to breast cancer.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1051

choices.text: p53
BRCA-2
Her 2/Neu gene
C-myc gene

questions.text: A female patient presented with a firm mass of 2 × 2 cm in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. She gives a family history of ovarian carcinoma. The investigation that needs to be done to assess for mutations is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) BRCA2

 

Option B:

 

BRCA2 is a tumor suppressor gene, and mutations in this gene are known to significantly increase the risk of both breast and ovarian cancers in bwith a history suggestive of hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The p53 gene, when mutated, can lead to a variety of cancers; however, in the context of a family history suggesting a hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome, BRCA1 and BRCA2 gene testing is more directly relevant.

 

Option C. Her 2/Neu gene amplification is associated with breast cancer aggressiveness and treatment decisions but is not a part of routine genetic screening for hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndrome.

 

Option D. C-myc is an oncogene implicated in the pathogenesis of various cancers, including breast cancer, but it does not have a direct role in hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndromes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BRCA2 genetic testing is indicated in a patient with a breast mass and a family history of ovarian carcinoma, as mutations in the BRCA1 and BRCA2 genes are strongly associated with hereditary breast and ovarian cancer syndromes.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1058

choices.text: Nottingham
Birmingham
Cunningham
Welham

questions.text: All invasive breast carcinomas are graded histologically with the following scoring system:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nottingham

 

Option A:

 

Breast carcinomas are histologically graded using the Nottingham Histologic Score, also known as the Nottingham Combined Histologic Grade or Nottingham Grading System. This system evaluates three histologic features: tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic count. Each component is assigned a score, and the scores are combined to determine the overall grade. This grading system helps in predicting the behavior and prognosis of breast cancer.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Nottingham Histologic Score is used for grading breast carcinomas. It assesses tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic count, each of which is given a score.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1064

choices.text: Initiate hormonal therapy with tamoxifen
Administer chemotherapy with doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide
Prescribe trastuzumab
Recommend radiotherapy for local control

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a palpable lump in her left breast. A biopsy is performed, and the histopathological examination reveals invasive ductal carcinoma. Immunohistochemistry (IHC) shows a HER2/neu score of 3+. What is the most appropriate next step in managing this patient's breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prescribe trastuzumab

 

Option C:

 

Trastuzumab, given its ability to target HER2/neu-positive tumors, would be the most appropriate next step in management for a patient with a HER2/neu score of 3+ on IHC.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While hormonal therapy is an essential part of the treatment for hormone receptor-positive breast cancer, the HER2/neu status of the tumor guides the use of targeted therapies such as trastuzumab.

 

Option B. Chemotherapy may be a component of treatment for breast cancer, but for HER2/neu-positive tumors, trastuzumab is a key targeted therapy that has been shown to significantly improve outcomes.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy could be part of the comprehensive treatment for breast cancer, particularly for local control, but is not directly related to the HER2/neu overexpression finding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with a HER2/neu score of 3+ indicating HER2 protein overexpression, trastuzumab is the most appropriate next step for targeted therapy in the management of HER2-positive breast cancer.

choices.text: An aromatase inhibitor
Selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) like tamoxifen
Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonist
Progestin therapy

questions.text: A 50-year-old postmenopausal woman is diagnosed with estrogen receptor-positive (ER+) and progesterone receptor-positive (PR+) invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast. What is the most appropriate adjuvant endocrine therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) An aromatase inhibitor

 

Option A:

 

For postmenopausal women with hormone receptor-positive breast cancer, aromatase inhibitors (e.g., letrozole, anastrozole, exemestane) are often preferred over tamoxifen. Aromatase inhibitors reduce the production of estrogen and are associated with improved disease-free survival in this population. Tamoxifen is more commonly used in premenopausal women.

 

Aromatase inhibitors are typically the first choice for ER+ breast cancer in postmenopausal women because they are effective at reducing the amount of estrogen produced by adipose and other tissues.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Tamoxifen, a SERM, can be used in postmenopausal women but is often reserved for those who cannot tolerate aromatase inhibitors or for premenopausal women.

 

Option C. Gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonists are used in premenopausal women to suppress ovarian estrogen production, which is not applicable in postmenopausal women.

 

Option D. Progestin therapy is not typically used in the treatment of hormone receptor-positive breast cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a postmenopausal woman with ER+ and PR+ breast cancer, the most appropriate adjuvant endocrine therapy is an aromatase inhibitor, which has been shown to be more effective than tamoxifen in this patient population.

choices.text: Blood vessel penetration by tumor cells
Tumor cells in lymphatic channels
Lymphocyte infiltration
The number of mitoses per high power field

questions.text: With regard to the malignant behavior of leiomyosarcoma, the most important criterion is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The number of mitoses per high power field

 

Option D:

 

  • The most important criterion for distinction of leiomyosarcoma from leiomyoma (malignant transformation) is the number of mitoses present.
  • Ten high power fields (hpf) are examined. If > 10 mitoses are seen, it signifies malignancy. If cellular atypia is also present, > 5 mitoses are enough to make a diagnosis of leiomyosarcoma.

 

When distinguishing leiomyosarcoma from leiomyoma, the assessment of malignancy heavily relies on histological examination.

 

The number of mitoses per high power field is a key histological criterion to determine the malignant behavior of leiomyosarcoma. A higher number of mitotic figures usually indicates a more aggressive tumor.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Blood vessel penetration by tumor cells is a feature observed in malignant tumors. However, while significant, it is not the most critical factor in diagnosing leiomyosarcoma.

 

Option B. The presence of tumor cells in lymphatic channels is another indication of potential malignancy and can signify the spread of cancer, but it's not the primary criterion for diagnosis.

 

Option C. Lymphocyte infiltration is often a sign of an immune response to the tumor rather than a direct indication of malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A high mitotic index is indicative of aggressive tumor behavior and malignancy, aiding in the differentiation between benign and malignant smooth muscle tumors such as leiomyomas and leiomyosarcomas, respectively.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th 1021

choices.text: Clear cell
Adenocarcinoma
Squamous cell carcinoma
Transitional cell carcinoma

questions.text: Most common subtype of endometrial carcinoma on histopathology is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenocarcinoma

 

Option B:

 

Adenocarcinoma is the most common subtype of endometrial carcinoma. The majority of endometrial cancers are adenocarcinomas, and they are often classified into two main types: endometrioid and non-endometrioid. Endometrioid adenocarcinoma is the most common subtype, while clear cell, squamous cell, and transitional cell carcinomas are less common subtypes.

 

The majority of endometrial carcinomas are adenocarcinomas, with the endometrioid type being the most prevalent. It originates from the glandular tissue of the endometrium and often presents in postmenopausal women.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Clear Cell: Clear cell carcinoma of the endometrium is a rare subtype and is typically associated with a more aggressive behavior and worse prognosis than endometrioid adenocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Squamous Cell Carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma of the endometrium is exceedingly rare because the endometrium normally does not contain squamous cells; they may appear secondary to metaplastic processes.

 

Option D. Transitional Cell Carcinoma: Transitional cell carcinoma is another rare subtype of endometrial cancer that resembles urothelial carcinoma of the bladder. This type of carcinoma is not commonly found in the endometrium.

 

Educational objective: 

 

Adenocarcinoma, especially the endometrioid subtype, is the most common form of endometrial cancer.

 

Ref: Robbins 10th/ 1010
